executive_summary: The Children's Fitness Center Franchises industry has grown over the five years to 2022, driven by rising per capita disposable income and growing awareness of child obesity. To help mitigate child obesity, some children's fitness center franchises have offered balance, coordination and other forms of training. However, franchises have contended with rising external competition, notably from afterschool programs, child athletic programs and child daycare programs, thus limiting revenue growth opportunities. Further, the COVID-19 (coronavirus) outbreak weighed on industry demand in 2020. Nonetheless, demand is expected to pick up as the pandemic subsides and a large share of the population has been vaccinated. Over the five years to 2022, industry revenue is expected to rise at an annualized rate of 0.7% to $574.7 million, including a 0.3% decline in 2022 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue growth over five years to 2022
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Over the five years to 2022, IBISWorld estimates that revenue for the Children's Fitness Center Franchises industry is expected to increase at an annualized rate of 0.7% to $574.7 million. Over the five years to 2022, children's fitness center franchises have benefited from rising per capita disposable income, coupled with rapidly growing awareness of childhood obesity and the importance of daily physical activity.

However, the COVID-19 (coronavirus) outbreak that occurred in early 2020 placed downward pressure on industry demand as parents refrained from sending their children to industry establishments due to coronavirus fears. As the pandemic subsides, some franchises have expanded in response to the increase in demand. However, prices have been kept low to compete with less expensive afterschool programs.
Further, the industry has contended with competition from afterschool programs, child athletic programs and child daycare programs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Revenue forecast for next five years
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2027, industry revenue is forecast to grow at an annualized rate of 0.9% to $601.5 million. During the outlook period, the industry is slated to benefit from an improved macroeconomic climate and positive demographic trends.

Anticipated growth in disposable income during the period will deepen parents' pockets and enable them to splurge on fitness programs for their children. Furthermore, 0.4% annualized growth in the industry's primary consumer base, children aged nine and younger, will bolster revenue gains moving forward.

In response to strong demand, some children's fitness center franchises will focus on expanding their class selection and the number of classes per age group, keeping children and parents satisfied with class variety and convenience.

industry_definition: This industry operates franchised fitness and recreational sports facilities for children aged 18 and younger. Reports in IBISWorld's Business Franchise collection focus solely on the operation of franchised outlets and excludes non-franchise data. They show the total number of franchise outlets, total franchise revenue and the average profit margin earned by franchisees. The reports also highlight the largest franchisors by market share.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

threats: Number of children aged nine and younger

key_trends: Higher levels of disposable income have benefited industry operators
The industry competes with a variety of other fitness activity providers
Some franchisees have pursued global opportunities
The industry has reached moderate saturation
Some franchisors have bolstered their use of technology

market_segmentation.segment_description: In 2022, individuals aged 10 and younger account for the largest share of demand, with 35.2% of total revenue. Typically, industry franchises cater to this demographic to help build healthy lifestyle decisions.

Individuals aged 11 to 13 comprise an estimated 35.9% of total revenue. According to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), males aged 12 to 15 were the most likely to engage in basketball, running, football, bike riding and walking for their outside of school-based physical activities.

Individuals aged 14 to 17 generate 28.9% of total revenue. According to data from the Physical Activity Council, individuals aged 13 to 17 were the most likely to have a decline in physical activity levels. As a result, it has been arduous for industry operators to appeal to this demographic.

products_and_services.product_description: Many children's fitness center franchises offer monthly fitness memberships. For example, Children's Fitness Center Franchises industry operator Gymboree Play & Music offers weekly classes that are targeted toward a specific demographic, including newborns through the age of four.

Athletic instruction and personal trainers, which may be provided as a service in addition to fitness memberships, account for an estimated 10.3% of total industry revenue. This product segment includes one-on-one personal training services.

Amusement and recreational services generate an estimated 13.9% of total revenue in 2022. This market segment includes services that are provided in addition to memberships, athletic instructional and personal trainers.

Other industry products and services include child care, spa services and the resale of items, such as food, drinks and merchandise. Together, other services account for 7.0% of total industry revenue, with 4.0% sourced from item resales.

tier_2_suppliers: Steam & Air-Conditioning Supply in the US
Electric Power Transmission in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Increasing awareness of the need for exercise, weight control, good nutrition and a healthy lifestyle among children is having a positive effect on children's fitness centers.
The level of household disposable income determines the amount of money spent at children's fitness centers.
Leisure time availability and the unemployment rate influence industry demand.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast has the largest proportion of establishments with an estimated 23.8%.
The Great Lakes has 12.9% of establishments.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Companies have own rules and regulations
regulations_points.regulation_description: Most companies in the industry have their own rules and regulations to protect children and themselves from potential lawsuits.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Comply with public safety and employment laws
regulations_points.regulation_description: Companies must comply with general federal and state legislation relative to public safety and employment; however, these can vary between states.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Subject to regulations on membership contracts
regulations_points.regulation_description: Operators are subject to regulations on the sale, financing and collection of memberships, including the Truth-in-Lending Act and state laws governing debt collection.
Under cooling-off statutes, new members have a period to cancel memberships and get refunds, depending on state law.
For operators selling food/beverages, advertising nutritional products is regulated by agencies like the FDA and FTC.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Subject to labor laws on wages, overtime, conditions
regulations_points.regulation_description: Industry operators are subject to labor laws governing relationship with employees, such as minimum wage, overtime, working conditions.
Amid COVID-19, state governments imposed closure of non-essential businesses like this industry, though some are easing restrictions.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Access to financing for start-up, equipment and maintenance costs
barriers_points.barrier_description: Companies wishing to enter the industry must have access to financing for start-up, equipment and maintenance costs. Equipment costs are relatively low and have long life spans.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Restrictive zoning laws and permit processes in urban areas
barriers_points.barrier_description: In urban areas, barriers to entry include restrictive zoning laws, lengthy permit processes and a shortage of appropriate real estate.

barriers_points.barrier_title: High cost and time to establish brand reputation
barriers_points.barrier_description: The high cost and large amount of time it takes to establish brand reputation is a potential barrier for companies.

basis_points.basis_description: Industry operators primarily compete on the basis of price and classes offered.
Industry players typically compete based on location, which is the greatest convenience factor for the consumer.
Operators also compete based on brand recognition; franchises with clean facilities and well-trained workers will generally have a loyal customer base, which promotes brand recognition.

basis_points.basis_title: Range of activities and age groups
basis_points.basis_description: Companies that offer a wide range of activities for both boys and girls in multiple age groups provide a further competitive advantage.
Industry operators may compete for customer service as well. Strong customer service boosts member attrition rates and develops a strong customer base.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Top 4 companies account for over 60% revenue
concentration_points.concentration_description: Together, the top four companies account for more than 60.0% of industry revenue.
The industry consists of many well-established franchises, with many locations throughout the United States, enabling the top companies to earn significant portions of revenue.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages are the largest cost for the industry
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages are the largest cost for the industry, accounting for an estimated 27.4% of industry revenue in 2022. To lower wage costs, many children's fitness centers employ part-time employees who are paid hourly.

Purchases include items that are sold on-site, such as food, beverages and merchandise. In addition, some industry operators may purchase prizes and other disposable products (e.g. arts and crafts) for classes.

Depreciation represents another significant expense item for the industry, accounting for an estimated 7.0% of revenue. To operate efficiently and profitably, companies in the industry must continually acquire up-to-date equipment.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Marketing expenditures account for 3.4% of revenue
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Marketing expenditures account for 3.4% of industry revenue. Franchisors may advertise via TV, direct mail, newspapers, telephone directories, radio, billboards, internet websites and other methods.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Rent accounts for 7.7% of industry revenue
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Rent is expected to account for 7.7% of industry revenue in 2022.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Utilities account for 2.7% of industry revenue
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Utilities are estimated to account for 2.7% of industry revenue in 2022.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Other costs include administration, IT, franchise fees
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Industry operators also incur other costs including general administration, IT expenses, franchise fees and insurance costs, which account for an additional 35.4% of industry revenue.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Children's Fitness Center Franchises industry has a moderate level of capital intensity. IBISWorld estimates that for every dollar spent on wages, industry operators will spend $0.26 on capital investment.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Capital investment in equipment, buildings, vehicles
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital investment is mainly in fitness equipment, buildings, vehicles, furniture and computers.
Over the past five years, capital intensity has declined slightly; in 2017, for every dollar spent on wages, industry operators also spent $0.27 on capital investment.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Labor is still significant due to workers needed
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Although the industry incurs capital costs, labor is still significant due to the workers needed for administration, training, supervising, teaching and maintaining the fitness center.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Overall, the Children's Fitness Center Franchises industry has a moderate level of revenue volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Diverse range of services minimizes volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Due to the industry's diverse range of services offered, and therefore varying participation rates for the different activities, volatility has been minimized.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Media attention on fitness and diet keeps levels steady
volatility_points.volatility_description: Additionally, media attention regarding fitness and diet has kept industry levels steady.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Less likely to be affected by technological advancement
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Operators in the Children's Fitness Center Franchises industry are less likely to be affected by technological advancement.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Services unable to be fully automated
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Due to the high degree of labor involved in the operational process, industry services are unable to be fully automated.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Instructors and trainers play a vital role
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Instructors and trainers play a vital role in the success of industry operators.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Low level of technological change overall
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The overall structure of the Children's Fitness Center Franchises industry has not changed drastically over time and, thus, the industry exhibits a low level of technological change.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Use of electronic payments and state-of-art equipment
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Many companies in the industry offer electronic payment options to members and purchase state-of-the-art equipment to attract customers and keep them safe.

FAQs.question: How well does your company market to consumers with limited leisure time?
FAQs.answer: When adults have limited leisure time it serves as a boon to the industry since they require the assistance of industry employees to ensure the fitness of their children.

FAQs.question: Do demographic changes have an effect on company sales?
FAQs.answer: The industry is heavily reliant on the number of young children in the United States, since operators specifically work with children.

FAQs.question: If your company benefits from population density, are you located in high traffic areas to increase your exposure?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators benefit from locating in highly-populated areas, particularly areas that are saturated with children.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to use rental agreements to save on equipment expenses?
FAQs.answer: Many industry operators rent the equipment that they use or enter into financing agreements with the franchiser.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored lowering wage costs through part-time labor and automation via point-of-sale systems?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators utilize employees in various capacities to limit wage expenses. For example, one employee will likely teach classes as well as work in administrative capacities.

FAQs.question: Has your company integrated web and mobile reservation and appointment systems to improve consumer accessibility?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators are increasingly incorporating technology, such as mobile class reservations in order to remain competitive.

FAQs.question: Do you offer membership agreements, tickets or passes that may be subject to state or federal regulation?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators are subject to 'cooling off' periods, which allow consumers to cancel gym memberships without penalty within a window of time after signing a contract.

FAQs.question: Are you subject to specific franchising laws that may hinder growth?
FAQs.answer: Since all industry operators are franchises, industry operators are subject to specific franchise agreements with the franchiser.

FAQs.question: How can you maintain superior service while reducing operating costs?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators employ multi-talented workers in order to save wage costs.

FAQs.question: Does your company have to purchase new equipment on an annual basis?
FAQs.answer: While some industry equipment has a long shelf life, such as balance beams, others, such as mats, need to be replaced more frequently.

FAQs.question: How do you promote your business? What marketing strategies do you use?
FAQs.answer: Being able to promote a business effectively increases awareness and attracts greater membership and local patronage.

FAQs.question: What training is necessary for workers at your company? What kind of training do your workers have to go through?
FAQs.answer: Skilled staff that can demonstrate the use of various types of equipment, assist participants and teach classes are important to attract repeat customers.

FAQs.question: How are you able to leverage economies of scale?
FAQs.answer: Children's fitness operators that have a large number of establishments and provide a range of services are able to attract and retain new and existing members, as well as reduce costs per member.

FAQs.question: How has rising external competition affected your business? How do you contend with external competition?
FAQs.answer: Children's fitness center franchises experience considerable external competition from after-school programs, child athletic programs, child daycare programs and other activities (i.e. full body motion video games).

FAQs.question: What age group accounts for the majority of your demand? How does an increase in the number of children aged nine and younger affect demand for your company?
FAQs.answer: The Children's Fitness Center Franchises industry primarily serves children under the age of 18, with a significant share of participants coming from the nine and under age bracket.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in per capita disposable income? How do you contend with falling levels of disposable income?
FAQs.answer: As disposable income rises, more families will have the discretionary income to allocate toward fitness center programs.
